title: Two objects. Same room. Two different temperatures?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why an object may feel warmer or colder to the touch, even if it is at the same temperature as another object?

options.label: B
options.text: The rate at which heat is transferred from one object to another

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the rate at which heat is transferred from one object to another?
Why did the aluminium block melt the ice cube faster than the plastic block in the experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: Because aluminium is a better insulator

options.label: B
options.text: Because aluminium is a worse conductor of heat

options.label: C
options.text: Because aluminium is a better conductor of heat

options.label: D
options.text: Because aluminium is denser than plastic

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason why the hard drive felt colder than the book, even though they were at the same temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the hard drive is made of metal and metal is always colder

options.label: B
options.text: Because the book is a better conductor of heat

options.label: C
options.text: Because the hard drive conducts heat away from the hand faster than the book

options.label: D
options.text: Because the book is denser than the hard drive

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary factor that determines how warm or cold an object feels to the touch?

options.label: C
options.text: The rate of heat transfer between the object and the skin

multiple-choice.question: Why is it more comfortable to stand on a bath mat than on a towel after a shower in winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the bath mat is warmer than the towel

options.label: B
options.text: Because the bath mat is softer than the towel

options.label: C
options.text: Because the bath mat conducts heat less quickly away from the skin

options.label: D
options.text: Because the towel is denser than the bath mat

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of an object having high thermoconductivity?

options.label: A
options.text: It will feel warmer to the touch

options.label: B
options.text: It will feel colder to the touch

options.label: C
options.text: It will conduct heat away from the skin faster

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why the infrared thermometer showed the same temperature for both the book and the hard drive?

options.label: B
options.text: Because the book and hard drive were in different environments

options.label: C
options.text: Because the book and hard drive had reached thermal equilibrium

options.label: D
options.text: Because the thermometer was not sensitive enough

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if you placed an ice cube on a surface with low thermoconductivity?

options.label: C
options.text: It would stay the same temperature

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concept demonstrated by the experiment with the aluminium and plastic blocks?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of temperature in determining an object's warmth or coolness

options.label: B
options.text: The role of thermoconductivity in determining an object's warmth or coolness

options.label: C
options.text: The effect of material density on an object's warmth or coolness

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of color on an object's warmth or coolness

options.label: C
options.text: By adding more details to the illustration.

options.label: B
options.text: To test the durability of the paper used.

options.text: To add colors and shapes to the pop-up elements.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: By designing a new type of paper tool.

options.label: D
options.text: By writing a story about pop-up books.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the animation process more complicated.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows the animator to achieve the desired effect.

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the number of frames needed.

options.label: A
options.text: Memory is a single, unified process

options.label: B
options.text: Memory is stored only in the hippocampus

options.label: C
options.text: There is a distinction between short-term and long-term memory

options.label: D
options.text: Memory is not affected by brain damage

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how does memory formation occur?

options.label: A
options.text: Sensory data is stored directly in the hippocampus

options.label: B
options.text: Sensory data is temporarily transcribed by neurons in the cortex, then transferred to the hippocampus

options.label: C
options.text: Sensory data is stored in the basal ganglia

options.label: D
options.text: Sensory data is stored in the cerebellum

multiple-choice.question: What type of memory is associated with the basal ganglia and cerebellum?

options.label: A
options.text: He was unable to perform the task

options.label: B
options.text: He performed the task perfectly on the first try

options.label: C
options.text: He improved over repeated trials, despite having no memory of previous attempts

options.label: D
options.text: He showed no improvement over repeated trials

multiple-choice.question: What is the distinction between "knowing that" and "knowing how" in memory research?

options.label: A
options.text: The difference between short-term and long-term memory

options.label: B
options.text: The difference between declarative and procedural memory

options.label: C
options.text: The difference between conscious and unconscious memory

options.label: D
options.text: The difference between sensory and motor memory

options.label: A

options.label: B

title: Feedback loops: How nature gets its rhythms - Anje-Margriet Neutel

multiple-choice.question: What is the key element of feedback in the environment or social science?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon called separate causal interaction

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon called mutual causal interaction

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon called internal causal interaction

options.label: D
options.text: A phenomenon called external causal interaction

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of positive feedback in an ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: Predators reducing the population of their prey

options.label: B
options.text: The buildup of humus in the soil after plants die

options.label: C
options.text: The removal of a forest making it vulnerable to erosion

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between positive and negative feedback in an ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive feedback is beneficial, while negative feedback is harmful

options.label: B
options.text: Positive feedback amplifies a particular effect, while negative feedback diminishes it

options.label: C
options.text: Positive feedback occurs in living things, while negative feedback occurs in nonliving things

options.label: D
options.text: Positive feedback occurs in the short term, while negative feedback occurs in the long term

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the population of lynx and snowshoe hares in an ecosystem with negative feedback?

options.label: A
options.text: The population of lynx increases, while the population of hares decreases

options.label: B
options.text: The population of lynx decreases, while the population of hares increases

options.label: C
options.text: The populations of both lynx and hares increase

options.label: D
options.text: The populations of both lynx and hares fluctuate in an up and down wavelike pattern

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an unexpected reaction to spraying pesticides in an ecosystem?

options.label: C
options.text: The reduced predation allows the insect population to rise

options.label: D
options.text: The pesticide has no effect on the ecosystem

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a feedback loop if one link is removed?
How do feedback loops in ecological systems interact with each other?

options.label: B
options.text: They play together, creating regular patterns

options.label: C
options.text: They have no effect on each other

options.label: D
options.text: They only interact through linear scenarios of cause and effect

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a habitat with strong negative and positive feedback loops?
What happens to an ecosystem when deforestation occurs?

options.label: D
options.text: The ecosystem develops and changes over time

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to an abandoned patch of farmland over time?

title: What can Schr√∂dinger's cat teach us about quantum mechanics? - Josh Samani

multiple-choice.question: What type of physics governs the behavior of macroscopic objects?
What is the term for a state in which a system can exist in multiple possibilities simultaneously?
In the thought experiment of Schr√∂dinger's cat, what is the probability of the cat being alive or dead before the box is opened?
What happens to the electron in a hydrogen atom according to quantum physics?

options.label: A
options.text: It orbits the nucleus in a fixed path

options.label: B
options.text: It is sort of everywhere in space, all at once

options.label: C
options.text: It is only in one specific location

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon in which two or more systems become connected in such a way that their properties are correlated, regardless of distance?

options.label: A
options.text: 25% for each of the four outcomes

options.label: B
options.text: 50% for each of the two outcomes

options.label: C
options.text: 100% for one outcome, 0% for the others

options.label: D
options.text: 50% for one outcome, 25% for each of the other two outcomes

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The laws of quantum mechanics allow for instantaneous correlation

options.label: B
options.text: It only occurs at very large scales

options.label: C
options.text: It can occur between two subatomic particles, even when separated by large distances

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a real phenomenon

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It will escape to a safer galaxy

options.label: C
options.text: It will become entangled with another cat

title: Should I stay or should I switch doors?

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the popular game show mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: He opens the door chosen by the contestant.

options.label: B
options.text: He opens one of the two remaining doors to reveal a zonk.

options.label: C
options.text: He gives the contestant another chance to choose a door.

options.label: D
options.text: He reveals the location of the car.

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of the car being behind one of the two doors not chosen by the contestant?
What is the best strategy for the contestant to follow in order to win the car?

options.label: B
options.text: Switch to the other unopened door.

multiple-choice.question: If the contestant switches doors, what is the probability of winning the car?

options.label: B
options.text: Because the probability of the car being behind one of the 99 doors is higher.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the contestant is more likely to win with 100 doors.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the game is more complicated with 100 doors.

options.label: A
options.text: To make the game more complicated.

options.label: B
options.text: To illustrate the same principle in a different context.

options.label: D
options.text: To change the rules of the game.

title: The past, present and future of the bubonic plague - Sharon N. DeWitte

multiple-choice.question: What was the approximate percentage of the world's population that was destroyed during the Black Death?

options.label: B
options.text: The disease was spread by rodent fleas

options.label: C
options.text: The host population was more vulnerable due to malnutrition and poor health

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the rapid population growth in Europe during the High Middle Ages?

options.label: B
options.text: A decrease in poverty and famine

options.label: C
options.text: A steady decline in living standards, marked by famine, poverty, and poor health

multiple-choice.question: How did the destruction caused by the Black Death change humanity on a societal level?

options.label: B
options.text: It led to an increase in poverty and famine

options.label: C
options.text: It led to important changes in Europe's economic conditions, including higher living standards and social mobility

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on society

multiple-choice.question: What was the biological impact of the Black Death on the surviving population?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a decrease in genetic diversity

options.label: B
options.text: It led to an increase in genetic mutations that conferred immunities to multiple pathogens

options.label: C
options.text: It had no significant biological impact

options.label: D
options.text: It led to an increase in the spread of the disease

multiple-choice.question: Why is research on the genetic consequences of the Black Death important?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help us understand how the plague was spread

options.label: B
options.text: It can help us develop new treatments for the plague

options.label: C
options.text: It can help us discover genetic mutations that confer immunities to multiple pathogens

multiple-choice.question: What is the current threat of an epidemic on the scale of the Black Death?

options.label: A
options.text: It is high due to the emergence of a drug-resistant strain of the plague

options.label: B
options.text: It is low due to the availability of antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: It is moderate due to the ongoing spread of the plague

multiple-choice.question: How does the bubonic plague continue to affect people worldwide?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It kills a few thousand people every year

options.label: D
options.text: It only affects people in Europe

multiple-choice.question: Why is learning more about the causes and effects of the Black Death important?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help us understand how the plague was spread

options.label: B
options.text: It can help us develop new treatments for the plague

options.label: C
options.text: It can help us prevent a similar epidemic in the future

title: How optical illusions trick your brain - Nathan S. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of retinal ganglion cells in the visual system?

options.label: B
options.text: To increase contrast with lateral inhibition

multiple-choice.question: Which part of the brain is responsible for recognizing faces?

options.label: B
options.text: Fusiform face area and others in the occipital and temporal lobes

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of lateral inhibition in the visual system?
What is the assumption made by the brain's visual cortex about the lighting of an image?

options.label: B
options.text: Light comes from a single source, shining down from above

options.label: C
options.text: Light comes from a single source, shining up from below

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the brain's visual cortex operating on assumptions about the lighting of an image?

options.label: D
options.text: The image appears in black and white

multiple-choice.question: Why do we focus on the eyes and mouth when recognizing faces?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are the most prominent features

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are the most expressive features

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are the most important features for recognizing emotions

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are the most easily recognizable features

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the brain taking shortcuts when processing visual information?
What is the role of the brain in constructing our visual perception of the world?

options.label: B
options.text: To actively construct a tailored, edited vision of the world

multiple-choice.question: What do optical illusions reveal about the brain's visual system?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is perfect and never makes mistakes

options.label: B
options.text: That it is flawed and always makes mistakes

options.label: C
options.text: That it uses assumptions and shortcuts to construct our visual perception of the world

options.label: D
options.text: That it is only capable of seeing in 2D

multiple-choice.question: Why does the brain use assumptions and shortcuts when processing visual information?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is busy and needs to allocate cognitive energy efficiently

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is not capable of processing visual information accurately

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not interested in visual information
